I feel there is a need for serious reflection in the field about what went wrong and why, before trust in Public Health can be rebuilt throughout the population.7/
It was inevitable that the necessary measures to mitigate a major pandemic would lead to frictions between PH practitioners and the population, but it didn't have to be that bad.6/

A third problem is that PH is largely viewed as elitist and out of touch, with little concern for peoples' immediate needs and struggles, financial or otherwise. The apparent inability of some PH practitioners to acknowledge tradeoffs probably didn't help.5/

A second problem is that PH is being perceived as paternalistic and self-serving. I suspect many may feel they have been talked down to, rather than respectively engaged during the pandemic, with their concerns and fears too often being dismissed as irrelevant or selfish.4/

Now more than ever, I feel PH should try to stay out of politics. This doesn't mean that the rights and wellbeing of any section of society shouldn't be fought for specifically, but that it should be in a non-partisan way, and not seen as a fight against others in society.3/

One problem is the politicisation of the field, both perceived and real. In the early stages of the pandemic being, I got involved in a discussion with senior PH practitioners. My views that PH should try to remain apolitical were deemed to be ignorant if not sinister.2/

And I get that me saying this is probably going to come off as class solidarity. I guess there isn't much I can do about that. If anyone has counterpoints, I am always willing to listen and change my mind. (end)

It doesn't make it okay just because they aren't low wage workers. Just like a lot of abusive work practices employed by big corporations against blue collar workers isn't okay. Which isn't to say that the level of grievances are identical. (4/)

However, I also sympathize with some engineers complaining that it is totally unrelated to their job description/contract. This argument has faced a lot of ridicule because these are well paid workers. But I think a breach of contract is a breach of contract. (3/)

For one, I think there is some value in engineers/researchers understanding the data generation process and being able to understand the challenges faced by the delivery drivers. It sounds like a well meaning idea to bridge the gap between engineering and consumers. (2/)
A lot of people are being judgmental of Doordash engineers who don't like the idea of having to do deliveries once a month. I really don't know how I feel about this. (1/)

No matter the course taken I think though it will go fast, because Omicron's infection rate is so fast. Hold tight, take care, and look after yourself, your family and your friends because Omicron is coming to everyone, quickly.

(France though looks like it is catching up with UK and DK quickly, in particular in Paris / Ile-de-France, and if Omicron takes off in PACA I guess we will understand even better Omicron severity in unvaccinated individuals).

Just as UK agonised in mid-december about how much one could extrapolate from South Africa on severity (somewhat it turns out, but it's complex), other European countries are going to agonise about how much they can extrapolate/understand from UK and DK, the early Omicron leaders

It is tempting just to go slow - lockdown to get time to see perhaps mistakes or successes other countries make - and yet lockdowns themselves cause harm (we've not been collectively good at measuring them) and some things we desparately don't want to lockdown, notably schools.

Faster, immune evading Omicron infection but with less inherent severity and new clinical approaches means we have multiple variables moving around at the same time; even more complexity for analysts and ultimately decision makers.

But we also have new weapons - eg anti-viral drugs (note a UK scheme to have pre-positioned test-at-home for vulnerable people with express couriered anti-virals to home to try to stop hospitalisations) and in-home monitoring for low risk discharge (oxygen meters)

Omicron's infectiousness over 2-vax, previous also means there is a new workforce issue of isolation - important to really be on top of for healthcare workers. This greatly complicates navigating Omicron.

Here there is often I think too much focus on aggregate country numbers (78% vaccinated) and not enough on age-stratified vaccination numbers; more complex, harder to aggregate, sometimes not easily available (eg, Germany) and harder to explain, but the most important variable.

Clearly the safest position is to have as many people vaccinated (3-doses, first dose the most important). It seems unlikely one can easily prevent exposure as Omicron moves through the population, so unexposed, vaccine hestitant people are the biggest risk.

What does an exit from Omicron need? We still don't know how much of Omicron's low severity extends to immunologically naive people, though the fast rising hospitalisations in US suggests not (though sorting out Delta from Omicron is still complex).

As such countries have set the course this week; in something like 10 days from now we will be settling into new "exit from Omicron wave" schemes. Worth noting that South Africa has pretty much got through Omicron (at least my reading from SA epidemiology twitter).
(If there is a pundit on this site or other location who talk with confidence about the trajectory of any country from this week I would be very skeptical of claims).

Holidays has also changed mixing patterns ( intergenerational), testing behaviour (far more deployment and use of rapid tests) + reporting. As such it is extremely hard to use current stats over these two weeks to know what is happening, though hospitalisations are most reliable.

I believe it is time to give in soon. Vaccine protection rates are as high as they may ever be in many places, and now we've got a couple of decent drugs. Pretending we remain in control, of sorts, is just becoming too costly.5/

It gives me no joy to announce the inevitability of SARS-CoV-2 becoming endemic, and in an ideal world I wished we could have avoided yet another respiratory virus circulating in the community (there are already ~200 including 4 HCoVs), but the world is just not always ideal.4/

Vaccine protection against infection is meh, though protection against severe symptoms, hospitalisation and death remains stellar (~20x), including against Omicron. There's also no moral failing in catching a respiratory virus. It's OK; it's life, which sucks at times.3/

One can don an FFP2, FFP3, N95 mask, or a hazmat suit, or whatnot, but at this stage, all this may achieve is to delay the time until some of us will get infected, and thereby marginally prolong the pandemic.2/

This is not an easy message to convey, even to those who have have already accepted that zero-covid was toast. Essentially everyone will eventually get infected by SARS-CoV-2 in the near future, and likely more than once in their lifetime.1/

Wilson's warmth & kindness were instrumental in the development of my career & in my belief that being a good person is the most important part of being a scientist. I will miss you E. O. Wilson. Thanks for the inspiration and may the ants be ever in your favor. 6/n

Wilson was happy I was into insects even though I was into the wrong ones. And we discussed ideas for the journal. I never actually got the journal fully going but another student got it going the next year. 5/n

I also got a p/t job as a shelver in the library in the MCZ area there and fell in love with butterflies due to the Nabokov material / collection they had. Many times when I went to work I would stop by and say hello to Wilson and he would always take time to chat 4/n

Then, he took me on a tour of his lab (I think he showed me ant colonies and other ant things).  And then we sat down for another hour and discussed Earth Day and student activism and other environmental issues. And yes, he agreed to be the faculty sponsor of the journal. 3/n

I figured, with a prof. like him this would be a very brief meeting. But instead I got to his office, and there was Wilson, and he was so excited about something. He had a new book out on Ants he wanted to show me. And we looked it over for like an hour. 2/n

When I was a senior at @harvard in 1990 I started an "Environmental Issues" journal as part of activities leading to the 20th anniversary of Earth Day. I hoped to get EO Wilson to be our faculty sponsor.  I phoned his office and arranged a meeting with him via his assistant 1/n https://t.co/0fyvH0ykky

3‚É£Regarding mutator RdRps, I'm afraid I've missed the point. Mutagens do not work by creating mutator polymerases. On the contrary, we see with ribavirin that they may even select for high-fidelity ones.8/n

It's also critically important that several sites mutated in #Omicron are highly conserved in SARS-related coronaviruses.The observed changes likely compensate for one another's deleterious effects, which would have been ~impossible to predict.7/nhttps://t.co/cGFWylPg7s

Instead, as @sarperotto and others stress, the real concern is MULTI-STEP mutations, which mutagens make more probable. It's noteworthy that #VOCs are indeed all multi-step conglomerates, the latest being #Omicron with almost 50 lineage-defining SNPs, mostly nonsynonymous.6/n

2‚É£Agreed it's important that SARS-CoV-2 already explores all single nucleotide (1 nt) mutations away from its genotype.But if the virus' adaptive sequence space were limited to single nucleotide changes, all possible VOCs would have already arisen in 2020!5/n

The real questions, then, are a) whether additional fit islands within sequence space exist for the virus (VOCs suggest they do)b) whether mutation rate elevation in millions of people by a mutagen will make their arrival and subsequent selection more or less probable.4/n

Thus, both analogies are inadequate: a) both are English; b) mine assumes a viable path between fit genotypes exists; and c) yours is a path in which all but the first steps are nonviable and would never be traversed due to negative selection (i.e., too high a mutation rate).3/n

Man: *getting frustrated* do you want someone?Me: yeah. I told you, I am waiting for my friend.Man: How about a woman?Me: *confused* my friend is a manMan: *now really irritated* Do you need a room for a woman?Me: I really am not looking to rent. (3/)

Man: Are you looking for someone?Me: Yep. My friend.Man: Are you from here (I assumed he meant the neighborhood)?Me: Nope. Man: Do you need a room? (I now assume he is also a realtor)Me: Nope. I don't live that far away.(2/)

Some context for those who haven't been to India. Calcutta is to Asia what Amsterdam is to Europe, in terms of the sex trade. But this native of Calcutta was surprisingly naive in such matters, even as a 20 year old. (2/)

The factors that mitigate morbidity and mortality in any setting comprise limited health and economic inequality, good and widely accessible healthcare and trust in authorities. Those cannot be magicked up during a pandemic, as they take years to build.3/

The countries that will likely emerge as 'pandemic success stories' relied on largely flexible and reactive measures adapted to the ever changing dynamic of the pandemic and to the local economic, societal and cultural constraints, rather than on any grand plan.2/

One of the biggest mistakes during the pandemic, and a source of immense frustration, has been the widespread assumption that the same mitigation strategies could be applied to the same effect in different settings.1/

‚ÄúWherever people are afflicted with grave suffering, it affects us all. Don‚Äôt forget: Whoever allows an injustice to continue for long is preparing the way for the next one.‚ÄùWilly Brandt https://t.co/AsF4OSd5Ud
5. With these improvements, normalise / manage as a year to year process the health burden of this virus (and others) alongside all the other things we do for health.
4. Improve healthcare capacity (particularly for UK, which runs very lean)
3. Improve detection and response of new variants and new viruses / bacteria. Omicron was better than Delta, which was better/similar to Alpha. Lots of moving parts to this, a very worldwide problem.

2. Improve structural factors of respiratory infection (note: will also help suppress colds, influenza etc) - good ventilation, perhaps routine mask wearing as in Asia, in particular in the winter (this is not so offensive to me).
1. Improve the treatmen of COVID the disease. New antivirals are the next weapon here. I still think there is scope for yet more dampening of inappropriate immune response.
Will we be doing this every winter? We don't know, but this is too exhausting and expensive (in multiple measurement ways) to be stable. My own sense is that we will have to improve on multiple axes:
(this strategy is waaaay easier to tweet than to do though. In particular the "protect everyone one can" means taking a view on how many unvaxed one can have to have the ease down ramp work).

But all European countries will need to plot a way out of Omicron post Xmas. The efficacy of booster vaccines means in some sense the same logic as Delta is present protect everyone one can via vax+boosters, ease off restrictions (maybe light) consistent with healthcare levels

Germany has announced more restrictions post Christmas; UK has decided not to change restrictions, at least until 27th Dec, but advocating more boosting and lateral flow testing (both clearly good things). I don't believe France has changed anything yet (correct?)
(Note: the UK data can't easily estimate much on older unvaccinated beyond "people are still coming to hospital" because the numbers of older unvaccinated people are thin for the denominator).

In Germany response to the late Delta surge has been good (in particular in Bavaria) but there remains a big East/West dichotomy, and old East German still looks like they have the biggest risks in older unvaccinated

At the same time, London's Omicron surge seems like it is growing less fast, though testing capacity issues are being reached in the UK. Paris is rapidly catching up with London, and rest of UK is following a growth trajectory.

The "headline" numbers for severity range from 80% lower through to 30% lower; the range here is partly setting (South Africa vs England) but at least as much in this definition "what does 30% lower severity mean in terms of this model".

(I know, I also wish it was easier to get intuitive understanding of these things, but this not how infectious biology is wired. It is related to some of the classic statistical Simpsom paradoxes which always stop people in their tracks until you break it down).

Here is a nice thread about this from @_nickdavies one of the authors of the LSHTM models about these headaches and just how hard it is to know if the "severity paramter X" in the model is the same as "severity as estimated in this analysis". https://t.co/td9nSii2kE

The headache is that early on to estimate this one has these biased (younger, big city) samples which one wants to use to model the consequence of infection (or not) across UK, or across Saxony with different age profiles and different vaccination statuses.

At some level this is fine - one wants the aggregate rate of people going into hospital in the UK (or France, or Germany) - accurately modelling the rate is the key thing, not necessarily unpicking the reasons. ...BUT...

I guess it reflects how much most of us crave recognition from our peers, with scientists probably being among the least immune to that incentive. This may not be entirely surprising given how the current system selects for 'scientific excellence'.5/

A difficulty for those navigating a 'scientific exile' is not to become bitter, mad, dead wood, cranks, or peddlers of bizarre theories. I find it intriguing how fragile the mental health of many 'outcast scientists' can be with most failing to survive their banishment.4/

The most effective way for a scientist to achieve fame and recognition is to be momentarily cast out from the corporation for their 'heterodox views' and then being re-admittted into the fold, after a paradigm shift renders their previously heterodox views, orthodox.3/

Whilst the process of science is meant to question the current dogma, there is a clear perception within academia of an in- and an out-group, with some being perceived by their peers as 'following the science', and others not.2/

Scientists are part of a corporation, like lawyers, bankers or teachers. Most tend to be on a personal level endearing, clever and thoughtful. Though, the vast majority follow the same unspoken rules and codes of conducts of the corporation.1/

Why do genes change mRNA levels when we subject an organism to (a)biotic stress? Genes go up, to: 1) fix/replace broken cellular machinery (e.g., photosystem subunits during high light), 2) activate stress-responsive pathways (e.g., heat shock proteins during heat)

In this 1984 paper, Mark Steedman describes a syntax - i.e. a grammar - that generates all valid 12-bar chord sequences, from a simple(-ish) set of rules. It is a context-sensitive grammar, as you can see from the above ii-V7-I rule.

Was reminded in this recent trip of all the different idioms and mannerisms of speaking Spanish and how I speak Spanish like a middle aged woman from Mexico City (because I learned Spanish from three of them).

Struck by this similarity, and looking for a neat grammar example to use in my final exam, I went hunting to see if anyone had looked into this before. And of course they have! Specifically, this paper: "A Generative Grammar for Jazz Chord Sequences" https://t.co/SpQ6eMgirb
It was, everyone passed to go to the metaverse. https://t.co/LdImXzeWUp

This is one of the most common turnarounds in jazz: the ii-V7-I. And it's very like a transformational grammar! Specifically it's a rule that changes the sequence "x I" (where x is pretty much any chord) into "x ii V7 I". In grammatical notation you'd write "x I -> x ii V7 I"

Accessing science is a privilege. For instance, I am privileged enough to hold a BSc and MSc and work in pathogen genomics full-time. Truth be told, given I don't have a PhD, there's still so much about 'how science works' to learn.

Science should be accessible to everyone and it's very annoying when those who don't work as scientists spout about the science out there and how everyone should "just understand how it works". Quite belittling, actually.

I don't really think it's down to the public to "just learn how science works". Not everyone has a background in science (and what an awful world that would be if everyone did!)Instead, scientists (including me) need improve our science communication. Especially in a crisis.

This article suggests the folks in favor of rapid testing are right https://t.co/Xc9mzV1qVjDoes this mean the first type of scenario never happens? Not at all. But it does support that a lot of people are using this information to know when to stay home.

Those against rapid testing typically imagine a lot of the first type of scenario happening. Those in favor typically think those situations will be more than offset by the second type of scenario.Who's right?

If humans use the test as an excuse to go to a family event they otherwise wouldn't have, cases could go up from the use of rapid tests, for example.In contrast if they would have gone to the event anyway, but a positive on a rapid test makes them stay home, cases go down.

How can we forget our old friend peer review. I'm not really sure how to reconcile the need for fast reporting vs business competition vs anonymous peer review. Maybe treat everything like a preprint?

Conclusions. Summarize your findings. Eg, group X is more likely to be vaccinated. State any speculations. Eg, due to possibly less access to vaccines. Give any call to action. Eg, supply vaccines to group X and further reporting is needed.
Discussion. Synthesize the results into knowledge. What do your results mean? You can combine the counts of vaccines per demographic in this example. State who is more likely to be vaccinated.

Results. What did you gather from all your methods? No opinions or conclusions are allowed. Make graphs and/or tables. Show p values. For example, if the story is about the pervasiveness of vaccines, display the counts of vaccines. Demographics.
Methods. Did you interview experts? Search the archives? Make observations? Use statistics? Write it out. Make me understand that you knew what you were doing.
Introduction. Explain it like I'm out of the loop. Link to previous work. Describe the importance and the impact of this work.
I'd love to see a media company take on the scientific method for news reporting. Introduction, methods, results, discussion, and maybe conclusion.

The quick identification and characterization of #Omicron is an example of regional and global collaboration. This manuscript has close to 100 authors that work day and night to make the world a safer place!

Vaccination, therefore, remains critical to protect those at highest risk of severe disease and death. The emergence and rapid spread of Omicron poses a threat to the world and a particular threat in Africa, where fewer than one in ten people is fully vaccinated

Neutralizing antibodies are only one component of the immune protection from vaccines and prior infection, and the cellular immune response is predicted to be less affected by the mutations in Omicron.

Close monitoring of the spread of Omicron in countries outside southern Africa will be necessary to better understand its transmissibility and the capacity of this variant to evade post-infection and vaccine-elicited immunity.

Genotypic and phenotypic data suggest that Omicron has the capacity for substantial evasion of neutralizing antibody responses, and modelling suggests that immune evasion could be a major driver of the observed transmission dynamics

Early identification has given other countries time to prepare their response. Omicron is now driving a fourth wave of the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic in southern Africa and is spreading rapidly in several other countries.

Conclusions: Strong genomic surveillance systems in SA &  Botswana enabled identification of Omicron within a week of observing a resurgence in cases in Gauteng Province. Immediate notification of the WHO and early designation as a VOC has stimulated global scientific efforts.

The notion of  immune evasion is supported by findings that show increased risk of SARS-CoV-2 reinfection associated with the emergence of Omicron in South Africa (See reference 48)  and  initial results from neutralization assays (see references 26,27) https://t.co/CjGBovw7L5

We thus argue that the population level of protective immunity against Delta is very high, and that partial immune evasion is a major driver for the observed dynamics of Omicron in South Africa (Figures 3B, 3D, and 3E). https://t.co/uIFUUJTfey

The results of seroprevalence studies and vaccination coverage (40%) in South Africa suggest that the proportion of the population with potential immunity against Delta and earlier variants is likely to be above 60%. x

The predicted combination of transmissibility and immune evasion for Omicron depends on the assumed level of current population immunity against infection by, and transmission of, the competing variant Delta, by prior infections with other strains, and/or vaccination

The growth advantage of Omicron is likely to be mediated by (i) an increase relative to other variants of its intrinsic transmissibility, (ii) an increase relative  in its capacity to infect & be transmitted from, previously infected & vaccinated individuals; or both.

We estimated that Omicron had a growth advantage of 0.24 (95% CI: 0.16-0.33) per day over Delta in Gauteng, South Africa. This corresponds to a 5.4-fold (95% CI: 3.1-10.1) weekly increase in cases compared to Delta. https://t.co/zW1WbhCdjJ

Bingo... There are indeed SARs-CoV-1 sequences in the listed samples in the paper. While it may be from heavily censored China, it is reproducible. https://t.co/nHYkKnRqge https://t.co/YbLyyvUlQl

This bam file just needs to be sorted and indexed and you are ready to load the BAM file into IGV for viewing. samtools sort ERR1091914.bam -o ERR1091914_sort.bamsamtools index ERR1091914_sort.bamCopy both of these files to a local drive that has IGV installed.

Next step is to map these reads with bwa mem on 4 threads and to pipe this into samtools so you get a .bam file out of the mapping. bwa mem -t 4 SARs-CoV-2_GCF_000864885.1_ViralProj15500_genomic.fna ERR1091914_trimmed.fq | samtools view -Sb - > ERR1091914.bam
Click on the genome tab in blue and you will get a .fna file. This will need to indexed with bwa.  bwa mem index SARs-CoV-2_GCF_000864885.1_ViralProj15500_genomic.fna

Once you have trimmed reads you can map them to a reference genome or assemble them. Lets stick with read mapping for the moment as assembly requires a bit more software downloads like megahit. You'll want to download the reference they mention in the paper from NCBI. https://t.co/kZ2Zrtg5Rs

This sample will be downloaded as a fastq file. This raw sequencing still has illumina primer sequences on them and these need to be trimmed with trim galore. /tools/TrimGalore/trim_galore ERR1091914.fastq

First we download the reads they mention in the paper using Fasterq-dump fasterq-dump ERR1091914This will download one of the samples in the paper that is listed as being contaminated with SARs-CoV-1.

If you want to follow along you will need a Ubuntu instance with a few free software tools installed. 1)Fasterq-dump (Free from NCBI)2)trim_galore (https://t.co/sz1SxS1urz)3)samtools (https://t.co/eAozUVwVk3)4)BWA (https://t.co/GASz0TFK46)5)IGV (Broad Institute)

There is no useful evidence to answer that question at this stage. The very preliminary data on Omicron hospitalisation rates from Denmark and the UK is not informative. Though, we shall know very soon ...13/

Conversely, if the relative mildness of the SA Omicron wave were only due to host population factors, this may bode well for other LMICs with similar epidemiological characteristics to SA, but not necessarily to other countries.12/
If Omicron were intrinsically milder, its impact would be expected to be lower anywhere, irrespective of population age, and immunisation rates from prior infection and vaccination.11/

This question of what is driving the lower CFR of the Omicron wave in SA is not just academic as an answer to it may allow predicting the likely impact in terms of morbidity and mortality of the spread of Omicron in other places.10/
The reduced CFR could be due to any mix of Omicron being intrinsically milder and/or the population in SA having acquired sufficient immunisation due to prior infection and vaccination.9/

Eventually, in the -long- term, biology will adapt to our plastics. It's what biology does. The problem is all the damage the plastic does until then.
Now, I don't think this is a likely ever scenario. We don't have our wooden buildings being eaten away around us (unless we do some majorly wrong things) and biology has had plenty of time with wood.

One sci-fi story I read expressed the idea that eventually biology will evolve to the point of rapidly degrading almost every technological material.In the story, a human ship landed on an old living world and the people got trapped because algae/etc ate their ship around them.

Think about how long it took biology to figure out how to efficiently break down lignified cellulose (wood). We can the time between when wood evolved and when the ability to decompose wood became widespread as the carboniferous period. This is when coal seams were laid down.

Good to see this research. It would have been astounding were this not to be happening, but it's still really cool.The difficulty is that it will likely still be a long time before biology can quickly break down our plastics. https://t.co/dTYwB0sxMn

We establish the frequency of these large variations across thousand-genomes and topmed cohorts, and demonstrate hundreds of them are associated with changes in gene expression (eQTLs). 11/n

Pangenomes improve over linear references, particularly for characterizing structural variations, which are large genetic changes that are, by definition, very different from the reference genome. We variant call tens of thousands of structural variations using pangenomes 10/n

We demonstrate state-of-the-art variant calling coupling Giraffe to Google Health‚Äôs DeepVariant tool: https://t.co/ly7BbhuGC7. Many thanks to @pichuan @acarroll_ATG  for the amazing collaboration. 9/n

To be technical, much of the speed and accuracy is achieved by focusing on mapping to the underlying haploid genomes, not the general topology of the graph. Mapping to embedded sequences is a much more constrained problem than general graph mapping. 8/n

What is unique about Giraffe is its combination of speed and accuracy. It can map to a pangenome containing 5,000 haploid genomes as fast as the standard tool (e.g., BWA MEM) can map to a single linear reference genome. 7/n
In Siren et al., we report a new mapping program, which we call Giraffe (ü¶í), that can take a short sequencing read and find its corresponding location in the pangenome, a tricky problem. 6/n

A key challenge in moving to a pangenome is that it is no longer just a set of strings; instead, it's a mathematical graph or network structure. You can think of the pangenome like a map of roads and places in which individual genomes are journeys: https://t.co/L7i9Frst1w 5/n
In Siren et al., we experiment with replacing the one reference with various ‚Äúpangenome‚Äù references, which can be thought of as ensembles of different, individual genomes. 4/n
Reference bias is a tricky problem; its use as a model is somewhat analogous to the issues with AI models that train with non-representative data and end up being prejudiced as a result. 3/n

The problem with comparing to one reference genome is that it works better for some samples and regions than others, i.e., it introduces a ‚Äúreference bias.‚Äù In short, the critical reference used by genome scientists does not adequately capture human diversity. 2/n

Many people do not know that we understand most new genome samples by comparison to the human reference genome, originally put together 20 years ago! A forward-looking Thread on our new pangenome mapping paper, out today in Science 1/n:

To summarize, this paper shows that:1. There's long cfDNA in maternal plasma and much more of it than we thought. What was an unknown unknown is now a known unknown. 2. LRS instruments can divine the tissue-of-origin at a single molecule level using methylation.
Then again, I'm not quite sure how important accuracy would be to this application, but I think it's probably feasible that both flavors of LRS could be used here.

While the authors used PacBio, I see no reason why nanopore couldn't also be used here as the technique is fragment length independent. In fact, if the library consists of both short and long pieces of cfDNA, the prep may be easier on nanopore.

If the market is really only concerned with trisomies/aneuploidies, is there any real (market) benefit for being able to detect more monogenic disorders at an early stage? I'm not quite convinced this is the case (yet).

Here's where I may need some outside input. Would a single-molecule method be able to have a lower limit of detection, that is, the ability to generate high-quality data earlier in pregnancy? Could one get away with more shallow coverage?

Even with this, I'm not quite sure about the economics of the preeclampsia application. Zooming out, though, what other applications might extend from these new discoveries. Might they support LRS having a presence in the NIPS/T market? Maybe!

Since the median length for cfDNA eligible for TOO analysis was ~1.8kb, I'd reckon an easy hack would be to re-run this protocol through PacBio's new programmable #concatenation method which stitches together small molecules into big loops:https://t.co/cfl6B5spVK

Then again, the method in the paper isn't optimized at all. In fact, most sequence reads were FAR below the optimal for PacBio sequencing (which is ~20kb). The molecules are way over-sequenced, which adds to cost, but only small returns on data quality.

Meanwhile, there's an up-and-coming (multianalyte) test being commercialized by Progenity called Preecludia which seems to have set the new standard for performance. Link below:https://t.co/sEkggowJAf

The current diagnostic paradigm seems lackluster (do you have high blood pressure, protein in your urine, or other non-specific symptoms after week 20)? While more accuracy/earlier detection would be great, these non-specific symptoms are SUPER cheap to detect.

So what does this mean?MAGs are great at capturing genomic 'dark matter', but they do not represent the very long tail of rare genes. For a true metagenomic snapshot of a sample's diversity, we arguably need both: the gene- and the genome-centric perspective.4/4

MAGs cover the abundant genes in a sample and can recruit >95% of *reads*, but they miss >40% of genes even in a well-studied habitat like the human gut (and >90% of genes in complex environments like soil).3/ https://t.co/SUYjHtI4Iu

The GMGC spans 300M 'unigenes': ORFs that were predicted from assembled contigs and clustered at 95%.From the same metaG contigs, we binned ~280k MAGs (>120k 'medium' & >40k 'high' quality). But these only cover 40M genes,¬†so ~13%.2/

I want to briefly talk about a side story in @luispedrocoelho 's study on the Global Microbial Gene Catalogue (see thread below).Metagenome-Assembled Genomes (MAGs) are extremely popular to probe genomic 'dark matter' ‚Äì but how much diversity do they really capture?1/ https://t.co/BEtX3tWBAd

We also find no association between yield and the overall number genes when accounting for breeding group/country of origin.Running a PAV-GWAS with NLR-genes alone reveals weaker effects and 4 linked genes, so it's an overall pattern - larger n in future shoulds work better

As hoped for, as NLR genes are always on like smoke detectors, so the organism has to spend resources it could spend on yield.It would not spend these resources on oil content, protein content, or the number of seeds, and as expected we find no association there!
Then, we ran a regression with country, breeding group, and the number of NLR genes with yield as the outcome, and voila, a significant negative correlation! https://t.co/sAMYneNzr1

The reason I personally feel in some weird peace of sorts with the Omicron variant spreading, is not at all because I want it to happen - I really don't - but because I largely accepted it will happen, whatever we choose do now.4/

I have mixed feelings about the incoming Omicron spread. I'd really wish us to be far more in control of nature and for us to be able to stem the spread of bugs, and then, keeping in mind that control over nature doesn't always serve us well, I feel weirdly relaxed about it.3/

Though, I'm afraid it may be too late already to effectively deal with the spread of Omicron in many places. It is spreading very fast, so fast actually, that by the time, we may agree on any effective measure to be put in place, it will have swept through.2/

There is currently a lot of discussion whether we should let the Omicron variant spread or not, based on arguments whether it may be milder, or how many people it may (re-)infect. This is great in a sense, as humanity is largely defined by its agency (genuine or fictitious).1/

Great work led by @Charlesi1 with the priceless and long-term collaboration of @FdlC61 and Pilar Garcill√°n Barcia. Supported by @INCEPTIONProjet @IbeidLabex @FRM_officiel Great comments and suggestions from the lab. 8/8
Plasmids lacking relaxases (MOBless) but similar to mobilizable and conjugative plasmids many also be derived from the other plasmids by processes of gene deletion. 7/8 https://t.co/9OAZfZyS4F

This rapid evolution is associated with changes in replicon typing and with the emergence of novel plasmid taxonomic units (PTU). At the micro-evolutionary scale, these derive by ‚Äúbudding‚Äù from the large graph of plasmids in a PTU cluster. 6/8 https://t.co/740Y5lbrT9

What are the consequences of conj -> mob transitions in plasmids? Changes in gene repertoires are fast in relation to relaxase evolution: plasmids with 90% identical relaxases have <50% homologous genes. Those that change of mobility type evolve even much faster.  5/8 https://t.co/jdOuSWP4s1

But sometimes these transitions have led to clades of relaxases that were highly successful and persist in bacterial lineages. This suggests specialisation of relaxases of mobilizable plasmids, e.g. in having the ability to interact with many different conjugative plasmids.  4/8

The phylogenetic trees of relaxases show clades of conjugative plasmids with frequent recent mobilizable plasmids and clades of ancient mobilizable plasmids with very few conjugative ones. Hence, most transitions to mobilizable plasmids seem to be short-living, deleterious.  3/8 https://t.co/Mqbg5y5RpI

We identified conjugative & mobilizable plasmids and show that many of the latter were recently derived from the former. Yet, one rarely observes the opposite. This results in a source-sink dynamics where conjugative plasmids frequently generate mobilizable ones. 2/8 https://t.co/ZIgTeB3uzi

A decade ago we found that ca. 1/4 of plasmids are conjugative, 1/4 mobilisable & 1/2 we don‚Äôt know. How do these plasmids come about is the focus of our new preprint: ‚ÄúEvolution of plasmid mobility: origin and fate of non-conjugative plasmids‚Äù https://t.co/xxP4nXyHCx 1/8

So the PKS complex is way larger than a bacterial ribosome. The 35 PKS modules code for 128 active sites (if I counted correctly...) with an almost perfect co-linearity between predicted PKS product and actually determined gargantulide structure. [3/5]

The BGC is ~215 kb - the 10 #PKS subunits are >178 kb alone and code for a protein complex with a monomeric predicted weight of 6.1 MDa (and after everything we know about type I PKSs, we can assume that they act as dimers). [2/5]

If you're interested in knowing more, please read our full preprint and BBS article (links above). And do check out @kph3k's visionary new book.https://t.co/KqSTMa2TY0

Such an approach walks the middle path between environments being too complex to understand‚Äîundermining the utility of behavioral genetics‚Äîand a simple reaction norm approach that applies non-human genetics to humans whose phenotypes are deeply shaped by both culture and genes.

Our BBS piece discusses the methods and statistics needed to fulfill Harden‚Äôs vision. The environment is seen not as an inert backdrop on which genes play out, but as a culturally evolving co-contributor to human behavior that is equal to or arguably more powerful than genes.9/

To understand humans, whose environments have been shaped by thousands of years of cumulative cultural evolution, requires models of environmental variation that are more sophisticated and dynamic than the reaction norm-based approach that Harden deploys.8/

The foundation of Harden‚Äôs program is the dynamic and regulable character of the human environment. But for a narrative that relies so much on the idea of a changing and changeable environment, it is strikingly stereotyped about the way in which environments actually change.7/

This sense of agency seemingly upends the status of genetic knowledge within public policy, from a nuisance that is best ignored‚Äîif there‚Äôs nothing we can do about genes, why focus on them‚Äîto a challenging yet promising instrument in the pursuit of social progress.6/

Harden draws attention to the modulation of genetic effects by factors like inequality and education. This dynamic character of G√óE interplay suggests that we possess the institutional means to steer aspects of the socioeconomic environment toward collectively desired ends.5/
In other respects, the book reproduces a set of hidden assumptions and conceptual limitations that are entrenched in the behavioral genetic literature.4/

The behavioral genetics Harden offers is an equal reconciliation of the biological and social sciences, in which data and methods from both traditions are smoothly integrated to help us understand difficult problems that arise at the intersection of both.3/

Harden's book provides an up-to-date understanding of gene-environment interplay and contextual modulation of genetic effects. The role of the environment and context are presented as inextricable elements of a science of human genetics, rather than as additional moderators.2/

Post Covid is our time. Let‚Äôs work across sectors to address  our universal burnout with better solutions for supports for the next generation. 14/
Affordable childcare, robust school and after school programs, and access to parent navigators are essential services needed universally. 13/
Forget about it if your child is special needs. That‚Äôs a part time job just to navigate finding care and near impossible without full time supports to implement. 12/
On almost any salary childcare is already unaffordable and there are almost no supports for managing after school hours and activities for school age kids. 11/
But, spanning academia and industry we need to have a serious conversation about supports for working parents. 10/
Then, across the board we need to talk about better supports. Academia needs to get its head out of the clouds and consider real pay equity and market value. 9/

I‚Äôm not anti-industry. Personally,  I found academia was a better fit. For others industry will be. But the myth of financial security and job stability that cause junior scientist parents needs to be broken down so folks can make a more informed choice. 8/

Even larger companies still have a bottom line and deliverables. Your senior managers who you want to become - they are fighting for a limited pool of funding from investors, competing products, etc. Many of the stresses are the same because again someone has to pay the bills. 7/

I hope many of you are able to watch Nicole's presentation #ASH21 on Monday, December 13, 2021, 4:45 PM ET for more details and to know how this research can lead to the new therapeutic avenue¬†in BL. Our preprint describing this work is also available:  https://t.co/EUDHBqjj94

These genetic subgroups also appear to have clinical relevance. Using the group labels or the mutation status of ID3, TP53 and DDX3X, these subgroups have significant association with progression-free survival but the associations differ between aBL and pBL.

Comparison of DGG-BL to IC-BL revealed biological differences in the landscape of non-coding mutations at aSHM targets and their gene expression profiles. IRF4, a gene relevant for B-cell differentiation, exhibited the strongest differential expression between DGG-BL and IC-BL.

As defined by predominant genetic features, we termed the new BL subgroups DGG-BL (mutations of DDX3X, GNA13, and GNAI2), IC-BL (mutations in ID3 and CCND3), and M53-BL (MYC translocations and TP53 mutations but with paucity of other drivers).

We performed an integrative analysis using WGS and RNA-seq from 230 BLs from 4 continents (incl. 100 adult BLs), and 252 DLBCLs, to investigate structural variations, coding and non-coding mutations, and profiles of DNA copy-number to discover 3 distinct genetic subgroups in BL.

BL is most common non-Hodgkin lymphoma in paediatric population and is often associated with EBV infection, but due to the rare incidence its genetic landscape in adult settings and relationship to both DLBCL and paediatric BL (pBL) remained largely unknown.

The Morin laboratory is excited for the presentation by our trainee Nicole Thomas at #ASH21, where she will discuss the new genetic subgroups we identified in Burkitt lymphoma (BL) https://t.co/slUOQltjjB

We analyzed 217 SAS-CoV-2 S-protein structures and 43 S-protein structures from other viruses. 44 structures of the apo-S protein (in its prefusion state or open states, 21 bound to ACE2, 116 bound to Ab (80 cryo-EM and 36 X-ray) 36 of variants, and 29 of other coronaviruses. /6

Many structures of excellent quality for cryo-EM, i.e., resolutions of 3 √Ö. Some X-ray structures of smaller parts interacting with Ab to ~1.5 √Ö. Amino acid coverage is important to ensure chemical precision, so we emphasized nearly complete trimers with N>900 amino acids. /5

We covered both apo-S-protein alone and in contact with ACE2 and many Ab. A main point here is that understanding rationally the effect of mutations on binding to ACE2 or Abs (antigenic drift) requires knowledge of the structure both with and without the protein. 4/

Why are protein structures central? They provide the 3d context to function and evolution beyond sequence variations -but this requires good structures of both the (apo)protein & its interactions with e.g. antibodies (Ab) and the human host cell-surface receptor ACE2. 3/

First, major credit to the scientists who drove recent innovations in cryo-electron microscopy -an outstanding achievement and reminder to politicians & funding agencies of the importance of basic science ‚Äìwithout it no excellent structures to understand SARS-CoV-2 now! 2/

It's too early to declare success, but we're heading in the right direction.We've had no regretted attrition in two years. We enjoy an amazing work-life balance. E.g., no meetings after 6 PM; no weekend slack or emails. And it's working https://t.co/3MSIV6MPNn 10/10

But it's not easy. We have to work at it each and every day. The key is to eat your own dog food. As the CEO, most weeks I'm hybrid, on premise T, W, Th and remote M and F. When I have the opportunity I work fully remote for a month at a time. 9/10

We bring together everyone each six months for a company-wide retreat. The retreat is mostly a social event and celebration of our accomplishments over the last six months. We announce promotions, give gifts, and eat good food. https://t.co/rXNWwhdwxk 8/10
Our new facility is 50% lab and 50% social hub for the BigHat team. https://t.co/rdOV5Vy3vFWe have weekly team lunches. We host parties, talks, and events. 7/10

Forging and maintaining connections with your colleagues is much, much, much harder. AFAICT, there's just no substitute for face-to-face interaction to build social bonds. Work over zoom works great. Social bonding, not so much. 6/10

Since we were founded right before the pandemic (fall 2019), we grew a super productive, remote-first work culture by necessity. We briefly discuss some of our innovations in our MBC Biolabs (@MBiolabs) graduation talk:https://t.co/Ls40GBqRiX 5/10
Our goal as a remote-first company is to make sure anyone can be productive and connected to their colleagues, regardless of where and how they work. 4/10

@BigHatBio has nearly 30 employees throughout the United States. Most work wherever they like. Many, though, work in our ~6K sqft, state-of-the-art synthetic biology wet lab, along with associated on-premise logistics and operations staff. 3/10

TL;DR: @BigHatBio remains a remote-first company, but remote-first at @BigHatBio doesn't mean a fully-distributed workforce. We encourage everyone to work in whatever environment makes them most productive. On-premise, hybrid, remote, or mix-and-match. 2/10

Rapid point of care virus genomics will greatly facilitate contact tracing, outbreak management and help provide tailored clinical management. We have the technology, we should be using it (10/10)

Lastly, I think @INSPQ @sante_qc should ditch qPCR screening of positive samples in favor of @nanopore sequencing directly at testing centers. More comprehensive, similar price to qPCR, MUCH faster than other sequencing tech, portable & established (10/n)

We also report some longitudinal sampling (2-4 times) of some employees/patients. The lower viral titers were sequenced, which can help understand intra-host variation. These samples are usually rejected for sequencing because gaps (9/n)

However, PHATE dimensionality reduction of clinical features helped identify a significant association between headaches, myalgia & sore throat and lower mortality; these are the COVID symptoms you want (8/n)

Statistical association between viral diversity and clinical symptoms doesn't reveal much, except some significance between the spike mutations and certain clinical features, but this is likely a sampling bias (probably a cluster of patients sharing a room/ward) 7/n

This was ch. 3 of my dissertation & marks my pivot from studying networks + collective behavior + info in computational bio (ant colonies) to studying them in computational social science (social media). Stay tuned for a 4th & final dissertation paper! 17/ https://t.co/PMcabTrWI2

üôè A special thanks to my advisor Corina & @andyguess for having my back throughout this interdisciplinary study. The fact that I‚Äîat the time, an outsider biologist & complexity scientist‚Äîgot to work with & learn from a rockstar expert in the field like Andy is truly unreal! 16/

Thus, the behavior of misinfo consumers likely looks strange to consumers of other news (& vice versa). As a result, we'd expect them to unfriend/break ties with each other to avoid being "misled" by friends who seem to constantly "overreact" to unimportant/untrue stories. 15/

Another implication of our work: Instead of changing minds, the impact of #misinformation may be that it sorts + socially isolates consumers of misinfo from consumers of mainstream news. The "reality" presented by misinfo will be very different than other info sources. 14/

Overall, our paper shows how the info ecosystem can (re)shape social organization. Polarized media can lead us to unknowingly curate the political composition of our social networks‚Äîno algorithms, homophily, or knowledge of friends' politics needed. 13/ https://t.co/PMcabTrWI2

In line with our model's prediction, we found that followers of partisan news lost opposite-ideology followers at a higher rate than you'd expect by chance, suggesting sorting into politically homogeneous networks. This wasn't the case for followers of non-partisan news. 12/ https://t.co/L8NZEHwwzR

To do this, we monitored the follower networks of 4k Twitter users who directly follow news accounts, evenly split among L-leaning followers of  @CBSNews (less polarized) & @voxdotcom (more polarized) and R-leaning followers of @USATODAY (less) & @dcexaminer (more). 11/ https://t.co/UPlym1muNk

With model predictions in hand, we then wanted to test some w/ social media data. (üôè ty @TwitterAPI!) We aimed to test if consumers of partisan news‚Äîi.e., ppl in polarized info ecosystems‚Äîlost cross-ideology social ties faster than consumers of relatively non-partisan news. 10/

Also, so much for "echo chambers"! People who end up in the homogeneous parts of the network avoid "unimportant" (to them) news at the expense of missing out on "important" news, including from their *preferred* news source. These chambers don't echo info; they silence it. 9/ https://t.co/VneV6st0IM

However, sorting in the social network is not uniform: the most reactive individuals (i.e., have a low threshold) end up in homogeneous networks, while those who get less worked up by friends/news end up w/ a more diverse, well-connected, & central position in the network. 8/ https://t.co/gxWQbtJoPV
Truth has been spokenüòÖ https://t.co/HqIyFkBcLI

Our model shows that initially well-mixed social networks will quickly sort by political identity when news sources assign different importance to the same topic. People end up shedding ties with opposite-ideology friends, even though they *don't* know each other's politics!  7/ https://t.co/vhx5hurFvZ

üîë model dynamics Pt. 2:üòØ reactions to news spread as complex contagion: ppl react using own threshold of importance + most react to friends' behavior before checking newsüôÖ ppl break ties w/ friends who behave out of sync with "reality" given by preferred news source. 6/

üîë model dynamics Pt. 1:üîµüî¥ people each have a political identity, but don't know each other'süóû people each have preferred news source, aligned w/ political identityüîî news sources report on the same story each round but may signal differing levels of "importance". 5/

We first constructed a theoretical model to simulate how reactions to news spread through social networks. We assume individuals participate in info cascades‚Äîi.e., observing & mimicking friends‚Äîand potentially rewire connections to others after evaluating their own behavior. 4/

Ok, we often hear that partisan news coverage drives political polarization by pushing opinions to extremes, but evidence is mixed ü§∑. Instead, we propose that partisan news fosters polarization by altering our social ties, creating sorted networks, e.g. below (from Twitter). 3/ https://t.co/9S2dao0LSX

This was my first big common garden experiment and I would not have been able to pull it off without a ton of amazing support at @eebtoronto, and some very special undergraduate students, especially the now graduate student Amalia Caballero! https://t.co/pfhA4CIh6c

So, we performed a direct test of Sauer's two alternative hypotheses‚Å†‚Äîhybridization versus var. rudis ancestry facilitating waterhemp's agricultural invasion‚Äîfinding strong support for the latter via 'environment'-dependent fitness effects along with de novo ag. adaptation. https://t.co/BmAkZoH5Lr

Ancestry strongly explained not only geographic clines in flowering time and growth-related traits, but was also in part confounding phenotypic differences among natural and agricultural environments. https://t.co/AB9fTZMTlA

Our first major finding was that of the two major ancestries segregating across the waterhemp native range, that southern var. rudis ancestry was overrepresented by ~8% on average in agricultural environments. https://t.co/us3Jhwn0EX

Thrilled to see this out!We tested classic hypotheses put forward in @sse_evolution by Sauer in the 1950s about the genetic source of agricultural adaptation in weedy waterhemp, combining WGS + a manipulative common garden + paired nat-ag collectionshttps://t.co/TvK6nVMwIP

This ms will come out in OA in due course in an excellent future issue of Phil Trans Royal Soc edited by @DrKatHolt Mark Achtman & @daanensen Hope you like this additional contribution to the many papers coming out on mobile elements.

Key message: The diversity and plasticity of cell-MGEs interactions, and those among MGEs, results in complex evolutionary processes where the source, or even the existence and origin of selection for maintaining a function in the genome is often unclear.

Horizontal transfer is costly to the donor and only occasionally adaptive to recipients. Mobile elements have evolved numerous mechanisms to control the frequency and timing of their transmission (on which bacteria have little control).

Key point: Horizontal transfer drives microbial adaptation but is often controlled by mobile elements whose interests differ from their hosts. Hence, one should be careful in assuming that the observed rates of gene flow are adaptive to bacteria.

Any definitely checkout all the ways our co-authors have been using the GNPS Dashboard in our huge set of use cases:https://t.co/TDtTDpzLUYIts quite the eclectic collection!
We‚Äôve been so lucky to have worked with such a great team of collaborators that have helped give feedback and shape the tool it is today. Without them, it would not have been possible.

At the end of the day, the GNPS Dashboard is about removing barriers to visualize, share, and collaborate on mass spec data analysis from anywhere at any time. We hope we‚Äôve made a few good steps in this direction with this work.

@malonekn, @AllegraAron, @michaeltmarty have also done excellent work to bring the GNPS Dashboard to their own classrooms for undergraduate education. Imagine leading a class through mass spec data analysis in a linguistics dept computer lab!https://t.co/wEpXBoKq0K

A second area has been the teaching of mass spec data analysis to students. Being able to send a simple link for my undergraduate researchers to analyze data has been transformational (no more installation troubleshooting).

One area that I‚Äôve also personally benefited from is using the GNPS Dashboard as a manuscript reviewer. Before, I rarely look at raw data because it was such a pain, but with GNPS Dashboard and more public data, I now validate findings in raw data to build confidence in results.

Proteomics repositories: @pride_ebi , MassIVE, @ProteomeXchange , and Glycopost. This makes hundreds of thousands of mass spec runs available at our fingertips. And if you have your own private data, you can upload it directly with a simple drag and drop!
So where can the data come from? The GNPS Dashboard supports public data from metabolomics repositories: @GNPS_UCSD , @MetabolomicsWB  @MetaboLights
See here Mithra Navarro showing how Dashboard facilitates data exploration between a PI and graduate student.https://t.co/iSGfmm95QO

With this in mind, building the GNPS Dashboard we aimed to enable mass spec raw data visualization from public or private data with a few clicks in the browser. Then, share your visualization or hop into a fully collaborative real time visualization session between collaborators.

As my collaborators know too well, I am lazy, and would prefer to do work to do less work. Working with @petras_daniel and our 40+ co-authors, we started with this simple frustration, and thought, wouldn‚Äôt it be cool if we could be the Google Docs of mass spec data visualization

And moreover, those old genomes haven't vanished, you can go download them, and look at them now, and see that they are still Alpha (or occasionally Delta with this one mutation).

And we didn't suddenly "know about Omicron" via a message from the gods! We knew about it because if you look at the whole genome it has about a gazillion mutations in addition to del69/70. And after literally 10 such sequences had been seen, scientists around the world noticed.

We classify variants (Alpha, Delta etc) using the whole genome for exactly this reason: some mutations are shared by different variants. If these were Omicron, they would not get called Alpha just because of this one mutation.

The thread looks at one mutation (del69/70) that's in Omicron, Alpha and some Delta in plots from https://t.co/1FkUd8VmhK. It asserts older sequences with del69/70 may have been "misclassified" because "we didn't know about Omicron". But we don't look at one mutation at a time!

You can't have it both ways - you can't be 'neutral' on the issue and allow it to continue in some states without implicitly stating a non-viable fetus has no inherent rights to protect, thusly undermining any rationale permitting outlawing abortion services in any states.

If SCOTUS "neutrally" deems non-viable fetuses are not guaranteed the same rights & freedoms that a fully realized human adult possesses under the constitution in ALL states, there can be NO constitutional path to limit the rights of pregnant women to terminate that pregnancy.

The thing is, you can't just willy-nilly restrict the rights of one person - unless you're doing it to ensure someone else's liberty is not impeded.The only limit to our own liberty exists when it negatively impacts another's liberty.

If SCOTUS decides to 'remain neutral' on abortion rights, they're effectively saying fetuses have no inherent constitutional 'right to life' per the USC.That means any attempt to outlaw it as such would then be an unconsititutional violations of fully living womens' rights.

Taxonomic debates are certainly interesting (I cover them regularly on the #AvianHybrids blog), but they should not distract us too much from studying fundamental evolutionary questions. (3/3)

When studying the speciation process in a group of birds, I do not really care whether they are called species, subspecies, ecomorphs, or something else. I am interested in processes, not patterns. (2/3)

I'm looking forward to seeing how the 2nd population does next year.

In year 7 I was surprised to find a few carrots had survived winter and were putting on seeds. (I started a 2nd population this year, with another mix (including a "black" carrot).)Now in year 8 things are back on track with neat carrots.

In year 3, the next generation had some very clear hybrids. I saved the better ones of those for seed.In years 5 things were going good. Tasty carrots in neat colors.I messed up in year 6 and killed most of the seeds I was saving. (The bottleneck I mentioned earlier.)

This project started with me growing a mixed patch of all the carrot varieties I could find seed for in local stores.Some grew well. Others did very poorly. I saved a mix of colors from the best and planted them the next season. (The cycle from seed to seed takes 2 years.)
